metadata.title: Epilepsy  Speech Therapy
description: Epilepsy, the most common neurological condition, affects persons of all ages and is characterized by “persistent, unprovoked seizures” occurring more than 24 hours apart; two or more seizures are considered persistent.(1,2,34) A seizure occurs when a short but intense surge of electrical activity alters the function of a part of, or all of, the brain.(2) Seizures can last anywhere from a few seconds to a few minutes and can have many symptoms, from overt body convulsions to subtle blank staring.(2) The term “ictus” is sometimes used as a synonym for “seizure,” and the time period immediately following a seizure is termed “postictal.”(2) For an individual with an age-dependent epilepsy syndrome, epilepsy is considered resolved if the person is past the applicable age and has been seizure-free  for the last 10 years, having had no seizure medicines for the last 5 years.(34) There are different types of epilepsy and seizures, described below

Types of epilepsy: There are many different syndromes and disease processes that can cause seizures; a patient’s seizures might evolve from one type into another over the course of the disease.(3) The following are descriptions of specific types of epilepsy: –Benign partial epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS): the most common childhood idiopathic epilepsy, with age of onset usually between 3 and 13 years; electroencephalography (EEG) is characterized by high-voltage  focal or multifocal centrotemporal sharp waves, usually followed by slow waves; these spikes seem to be activated by sleep(4) -Prognosis generally is good; however, long-term learning, language, and behavioral deficits might be present(4) -BECTS has been associated with other childhood syndromes, including continuous spike-wave  syndrome, electrical status epilepticus during sleep, acquired epileptic frontal syndrome, Landau-Kleffner syndrome, and early developmental dysphasia(4) -For detailed information on Landau-Kleffner syndrome, see Clinical Review…Landau-Kleffner  Syndrome: Communicative Disorders ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709047 –Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME): a common epilepsy syndrome marked by onset in the early teenage years; strong genetic component with symptoms such as myoclonic, generalized tonic-clonic,  and absence seizures (see below for seizure descriptions)(4) -Although JME appears to be a lifelong syndrome, symptoms respond favorably to drug treatment –Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE): an epilepsy syndrome characterized by mesial temporal sclerosis (loss of neurons and scarring in the temporal lobe)(4) -Most common form of epilepsy; seizures originate in the temporal lobe(5)  -Incidence of seizures might be significantly lessened or eliminated by temporal lobectomy(4,5) -There also exists a nonmesial temporal lobe epilepsy; patients do not have the same lesions/sclerosis as patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy(5) –Nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy (NFLE): an epilepsy syndrome characterized by paroxysmal arousals (sudden, brief arousals from sleep), hyperkinetic seizures, asymmetric bilateral tonic seizures, and/or epileptic nocturnal wanderings (sleepwalking behaviors)(4)

Types of seizures: There are several different types of seizures. Patients with epilepsy might experience one or more types of seizure(2) –Autonomic seizures: very rare; associated with an change in the autonomic system, such as tachycardia(3) –Dialeptic seizures: a term for a seizure involving loss of consciousness, regardless of the underlying type of epilepsy(3) –Epileptic spasms: tonic and myoclonic features; generally occur between the ages of 3 and 12 months; also referred to as infantile spasms; related to West syndrome; infants who present with these spasms might develop other types of seizures at ages 3–5 years(3) –Generalized seizures (affecting the entire brain)(1,2) -Absence: most common in children; very short seizure characterized by a blank stare and brief loss of consciousness; sometimes accompanied by rapid eye blinking and/or chewing movements(2) -Atonic: marked by a sudden loss of muscle tone resulting in a subsequent loss of posture(3) -Tonic-clonic:  also referred to as grand mal seizures; usually associated with loss of consciousness; often begin with an abrupt cry, followed by a fall and rigidity (tonic phase); progress to muscle twitches, shallow or temporarily suspended breathing, and/or alteration in skin color (clonic phase); might involve loss of bladder or bowel control; seizure usually lasts several minutes, followed by confusion and exhaustion(2,3) -Myoclonic: involve sudden jerking movements that usually involve both sides of the body; movements might be very subtle or very blatant(3) -Versive seizures: characterized by continued unnatural turning of the eyes and head to one side; might occur immediately prior to a tonic-clonic seizure(3) –Partial seizures (involving a focal part of the brain)(1,2) -Simple: consciousness generally is unimpaired and seizure might present with motor signs, somatosensory or sensory symptoms (e.g., olfactory hallucinations), autonomic symptoms, or psychic symptoms (i.e., disturbances of higher cortical functions such as speech and language)(1,2) -Akinetic seizures: marked by an incapacity to execute voluntary movements(3) -Aphasic seizures: characterized by an inability to use or comprehend spoken language(3) -Automotor seizures: exemplified by manual and oral automatisms such as chewing, swallowing, lip smacking, or hand movements; occur commonly with temporal lobe epilepsies(3) -Gelastic seizures: seizure characterized by laughing(3) -Hypermotor seizures: seizures are usually short in duration and consciousness is maintained; patient presents with large, violent movements of proximal body segments(3) -Hypomotor seizures: seizure activity that occurs in patients whose state of consciousness cannot be assessed during or after the seizure (such as infants or severely intellectually disabled patients); motor activity is either significantly reduced or completely absent(3) -Complex (similar to simple partial seizures; however, patient loses consciousness and generally has amnesia regarding the event)(1,2) –Nonepileptic seizures (episodic, paroxysmal events that are not related to abnormal electrical activity in the brain)(2) –Status epilepticus: prolonged, repetitive seizure activity that lasts longer than 20 to 30 minutes, during which time the patient is unconscious; status epilepticus is a medical emergency associated with poor functional outcomes; can result in death(2,3)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: The following signs and symptoms of speech/language impairment have been reported in patients with epilepsy: –Aphasia (ictal and postictal)(3,6,7) -Generally resulting from seizure activity in the patient’s speech-dominant  hemisphere(3,6) -Aphasia can occur during or after the seizure(7) -In a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study conducted in the United Kingdom with 21 children with left focal epilepsy (ages 5–12  years) and 48 neurotypical children (ages 4–12  years), researchers found that children with  left focal epilepsy were unable to recruit the ventral system during language tasks. In the neurotypical children, both ventral and dorsal systems of the brain were activated during language tasks. Lack of ventral system recruitment was also consistent with poorer language abilities as measured by standardized assessments of language (Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals, Fourth Edition [CELF-4]  for ages 5+ or CELF-Preschool  edition[CELF-P],  as well as the Expressive One Word Picture V ocabulary Test [EOWPVT])(35) –Apraxia of speech(7) –Cognitive or psychosocial deficits(7,8) -In a population-based  study in Norway,researchers compared children with epilepsy to a typically developing control group and found that children with epilepsy, as a group, develop psychosocial problems, mild cognitive impairment, and executive functioning deficits more frequently than typically developing peers(8) –Dysarthria(7) –Speech automatisms (involuntary, undirected words or phrases; might occur during or after the seizure) -Speech automatisms in a second language (SLSAs)(6) -Rare; spoken in a patient’s second language which the patient might produce during a complex partial seizure and/or an atypical absence seizure -Foreign language ictal speech automatisms (FLISAs)(9) -Extremely rare; spoken by a monolingual patient in a foreign language -Only ever documented in male patients with nondominant hemisphere temporal lobe epilepsy

The outward signs and symptoms of epilepsy include those associated with seizures. These include but are not limited to: –Body convulsions(2) –Loss of consciousness(2,3) –Blank stare(2) –Smacking of the lips(2) –Jerking of the arms and legs(2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with epilepsy often experience depression and emotional disorders due to their chronic medical problems, social isolation, and speech, language, and/or cognitive differences.(2) The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must proceed with sensitivity during evaluations of speech, language, and cognition and refer to psychiatry or psychology as needed
Maintain awareness of and sensitivity to cultural differences during any evaluation of speech, language, or cognitive abilities

risk factors: Sex (more common in males vs. females) (1)

overall contraindications precautions: If a patient is experiencing a seizure during a speech evaluation or therapy session Stay calm and reassure other individuals nearby that the patient will be okay(2) Do not hold the patient down or try to restrict his or her movements(2) Time the seizure (see below regarding specific time-related precautions)(2) Clear an area around the patient of anything hard or sharp(2) Loosen anything around the patient’s neck that could restrict breathing or cause choking(2) Put something flat and soft under the patient’s head(2) Turn the patient gently onto one side to help keep the airway clear(2) Do not try to force the patient’s mouth open. A person having a seizure CANNOT swallow his or her tongue. Efforts to restrain the tongue could injure the patient’s teeth or jaw(2)  Do not attempt CPR except in the unlikely event that the patient does not start breathing again after the seizure has ended(2) Stay with the patient until the seizure ends naturally(2) Be gentle and reassuring as the patient’s consciousness returns(2) Call a taxi, friend, or relative to help the patient get home if he or she seems confused or unable to get home independently(2)

Patients with epilepsy can experience seizures at any time; if a patient experiences a seizure that lasts longer than 5 minutes, seek medical attention(2) After 10 minutes of uninterrupted seizure activity, a patient might be experiencing status epilepticus (prolonged seizure activity lasting over 30 minutes). Call 911. This is a medical emergency with a poor prognosis(2)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with epilepsy often experience depression and emotional disorders due to their chronic medical problems, social isolation, and speech, language, and/or cognitive differences.(2) The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must proceed with sensitivity during evaluations of speech, language, and cognition and refer to psychiatry or psychology as needed
Maintain awareness of and sensitivity to cultural differences during any evaluation of speech, language, or cognitive abilities

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was epilepsy diagnosed in the patient? What type of epilepsy has been diagnosed? What types of seizures does the patient experience and how frequent are their occurrence?

course of treatment.medical management: The goal of medical management for epilepsy is the elimination of seizures(10)
surgical management: Surgical management:  If a patient with epilepsy has been prescribed two or three drug regimens and seizures are not under control (intractable epilepsy), the patient might be a candidate for surgery(12,13)
Anterior temporal lobectomy is the most common surgical procedure used to treat epilepsy(5,13)

In a prospective case study with an 18-year-old female patient who underwent 2 right temporal lobectomies for intractable epilepsy, researchers found that the second procedure resulted in severely impaired speech recognition in noise. Prior to the first procedure, the patient’s auditory processing scores in quiet and noisy environments were within normal limits. After the first procedure (which was relatively conservative), speech recognition in quiet environments was still normal and speech recognition in noise was slightly reduced, but still within normal limits. The patient required further resection of the temporal lobe because the seizures continued. After the second surgery, in which her right superior temporal gyrus and residual temporal lobe tissue was removed, speech recognition in quiet was still intact; however, speech processing in noise was severely impaired(31)
Hemispherectomy (removal of an entire hemisphere of the brain; for very severe epilepsy; usually performed only on children)(13)

Corpus callosotomy (surgery to sever the corpus callosum, which connects the two brain hemispheres, thereby interrupting the distribution of seizures from one hemisphere to another; also for very severe epilepsy; most candidates
for this surgery have intellectual disability and/or LennoxGastaut  syndrome)(13)

Evidence-based  guidelines for vagal nerve stimulation developed by the American Academy of Neurology cite level C (weak) evidence to support the consideration of vagal nerve stimulation for children with epilepsy, for
LennoxGastaut-associated  seizures, and for improving mood in adults with epilepsy(29)

Authors of a case study reported dyspnea and dysphonia in a 59-year-old  male with refractory epileptic seizures for years following post vagal nerve stimulation device implantation. The episodes of dysphonia and dyspnea were associated with activation of the device. The patient participated in voice therapy, which was helpful for improving dysphonia; however, the episodes of dyspnea continued with vagal nerve stimulation device activation. With the respiratory and phonatory strategies he learned, he was able to manage the dyspnea and no longer experienced “breathing attacks”(33)
Goal of brain surgery for patients with epilepsy is improved quality of life and seizure control(5)
Prior to surgery, the patient might undergo language mapping of the brain to identify the patient’s individual language centers(5)

Electrocortical stimulation of the brain is performed during language tasks (such as confrontation naming) and errors are recorded; if a patient makes a naming error while a specific part of his or her brain is being stimulated, it is presumed that this part of the brain houses language functions
The mapping is completed prior to surgery so that when the lobectomy is performed, the surgeons are able to preserve as much of the patient’s functional language centers as possible

In a pilot study conducted in Canada involving two patient case studies, researchers introduced an intraoperative language mapping technique to individually tailor the language mapping to each patient; both patients had good language outcomes 6 weeks postoperatively; scores of one of the patients were within normal range and the other had only a mild language deficit(5)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the primary physician and/or neurologist have prescribed; are they being taken? Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs)(10,11,12) AEDs are used to control neuronal excitability or improve inhibitory neurotransmission, subsequently reducing seizure activity in patients with epilepsy(12) AEDs block seizures; however, they do not appear to treat the underlying epilepsy(12) AEDs include valproate/valproic acid, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and phenobarbital(10)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for individuals suspected of having epilepsy are:
History and physical from patient’s primary physician, as well as neurologist
Imaging studies (CT scan, chest X-ray,  MRI, fMRI)(4,16)
To be completed by qualified psychiatrist or neuropsychologist
Should be completed prior to the start of treatment for epilepsy as well as any time the drug regimen is changed(11)
Might include IQ testing (Stanford-Binet; Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Revised [WISC-R])(8)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., special diets) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help A ketogenic diet is a high-fat,  average protein, and low-carbohydrate  diet intended to treat intractable epilepsy; commonly used in patients for whom surgery is unadvisable(2) Approximately one third of children who try the ketogenic diet become seizure free, or almost seizure free; one third improve, but still have some seizures; the last one third either do not respond at all or find it too difficult to continue with the diet, either because of side effects or because they cannot tolerate the food(2)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, physical, cognitive, or psychological therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there factors (such as lights or noise) that seem to trigger, aggravate, or ameliorate seizures?(2) -Side effects of AEDs might exacerbate existing cognitive-communication  deficits(19) -AEDs have been linked to postoperative delirium, reduced cognitive processing speed, impaired attention and short-term recall, and reduced verbal fluency(19)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: What symptoms does the patient have during his or her seizures?  -Does the patient experience auras? -An aura is a subjective symptom of a seizure(3) -An aura is a “warning” sign that occurs immediately prior to a seizure; a patient might report odd sensations in specific parts of the body(3) -Document nature of symptoms (visual, auditory, olfactory, gustatory, psychic, abdominal, autonomic and/or somatosensory)(3)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables (such as bright lights)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Patients with epilepsy sometimes have difficulty sleeping and/or report that sleep is not restful(4)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula? Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? Does the patient require ventilator support?Document psychosocial status and/or behavioral problems -In a study with 90 children with epilepsy conducted in Canada, researchers found that verbal memory and emotional and behavioral difficulty were associated with increased risk of poor health-related  quality of life(30) -If the patient or patient’s family reports symptoms of depression, anxiety, or other psychosocial or behavioral disturbance, refer to behavioral specialist or mental health professional for additional assessmentDocument hearing abilities, including hearing loss, history of ear infections, and use of hearing aids or cochlear implants Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of another developmental or neurological disorder?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or family/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Reproductive dysfunction, including polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothalamic amenorrhea, premature ovarian failure, and functional hyperprolactinemia, occur more commonly in patients with epilepsy compared to the general population(10) Obesity/weight gain is associated with a ketogenic diet and valproate/valproic acid(10) Patients with epilepsy are at an increased risk for bone fractures when compared to the nonepileptic population(10) Long-term  use of AEDs might affect a patient’s thyroid function(10)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient and/or caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing (including depression or anxiety)

social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Does the patient require use of a communication device? -Does the patient require hearing aids or cochlear implants? If so, are they in good working order? -Does the patient wear glasses? -Does the patient require a cane or walker?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does patient live (e.g., family members, caregivers)? -Identify if there are barriers to age appropriate independence in the home; any modifications necessary?  -Has the home been modified in any way to promote patient safety? -Is the patient exposed to any other languages at home, at school, or in the community? -What percentage of time is each language spoken around/to the patient? What is the patient’s fluency level in each language?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Patients with epilepsy might exhibit speech and/or language impairment as a result of the disease and/or the treatment (i.e., AEDs or lobectomy).(5) A full speech/language evaluation to include standardized tests of speech and language might be performed at the therapist’s discretion –In a study conducted in the United States, researchers compared the performance of 17 patients with temporal lobe epilepsy on memory and language tasks to the performance of 17 healthy age-matched  control subjects(22) -Patients with left-sided  temporal lobe epilepsy obtained significantly lower scores in memory, letter fluency, and naming compared to controls -Patients with right-sided  temporal lobe epilepsy obtained significantly lower scores in letter fluency and naming compared to controls –In a study conducted in the United States, researchers examined language deficits following damage to the left inferior8 patients with left inferior temporal damage due to stroke and 8 patients who had undergone a left anterior temporal lobectomy(23)  -Focal damage to the left inferior temporal lobe resulted in significant anomia, characterized by semantically appropriate circumlocution -Patients had increased difficulty with naming living items vs. naming nonliving items –In a study conducted in Sweden, researchers compared 20 children with epilepsy (and without concomitant learning disability, cerebral palsy, or autism spectrum disorder [ASD]) to 30 typically developing children; all of the children were between 6 years 0 months and 6 years 11 months(18) -Investigators concluded that children with epilepsy might still develop specific speech, receptive and expressive language, auditory attention, and/or visuoperceptual deficits -Compared to the typically developing children, children with epilepsy had difficulty with short-term  and narrative recall and oral motor ability, including positions and movements, and took longer to process information –In a study conducted in Austria, researchers compared 20 children aged 6–15  years with a diagnosis of BECTS to 20 age-matched  healthy controls; researchers tested children in the domains of IQ, expressive and receptive grammar, expressive and receptive vocabulary, auditory discrimination and verbal memory, reading and writing skills, and school performance(24) -When compared to the test scores of the typically developing subjects, the children with BECTS had significantly worse scores in the domains of adjective derivations, expressive grammar, comprehension of emotionally salient content, and receptive and expressive vocabulary -No significant differences were found in auditory discrimination abilities, auditory verbal memory, or reading and writing skills –In a study conducted in the Netherlands, researchers compared fMRI results from 34 patients with cryptogenic (i.e., nonsymptomatic) localization-related  epilepsy with an epileptic focus in the frontal or temporal lobes to those taken from 19 healthy controls(25) -The patients with epilepsy had significantly more difficulties in language function, as evidenced by lower scores on word-generation,  word-fluency,  and reading tests -Additionally, the reduced language skills in the patients with epilepsy were correlated with a loss of functional connectivity in the language networks of the brain when compared to the brains of healthy controls –In a study conducted in the Netherlands, researchers found that children with epilepsy were more likely to have pragmatic language deficits than children with other neurological disorders or typically developing children(26) -Researchers compared the performance on the Children’s Communication Checklist (CCC) of 30 children with epilepsy to that of 30 children with various neurological disorders other than epilepsy and 30 typically developing children(26) -In comparison to the typically developing children, both of the other groups had greater prevalence of pragmatic language difficulties; however, these deficits were significantly more profound in the epilepsy group(26) –In a study conducted in the United States with 25 children with focal, localization-related  epilepsy, researchers found that children with epilepsy had poorer language and narrative production abilities than did typically developing peers(28)those with a recent diagnosis of epilepsy and minimal prior seizure experience (n = 10) and those with chronic history of epilepsy and frequent seizure activity (n = 15). Each of these groups was then age- and gender-matched  to a control group of typically developing peers without epilepsy(28)the CELF-4,  or for children under age 5 years, the CELF-P.  Additionally, narratives were elicited using the wordless picture book Frog, Where Are You?  (28) -Children with epilepsy, as a group, scored significantly lower than age- and gender-matched, typically developing peers on the standardized tests of language abilities (CELF-4  [current edition is the CELF-5],  CELF-P  [current edition is the CELP-P-2])(28) -On average, the language scores of the children with epilepsy fell within 1 standard deviation (SD) below the normative mean, which, although significantly below the scores of the children without epilepsy, might not trigger a diagnosis of language impairment or qualify these children for services in a public school system; however, guidelines for each school system vary(28) -The largest differences in language ability were observed in narrative production. Structural analysis and listener judgments revealed that the children with epilepsy produced shorter utterances with fewer scorable story elements; often the children with epilepsy produced more words but provided less information in a narrative as compared to the typically developing peers(28)  -The group of children with chronic epilepsy had the greatest language differences/impairments relative to the typically developing control group versus the group of children with recently diagnosed epilepsy compared to their age-/gender-matched  typically developing control group(28) -All of the children with epilepsy in this study were on AEDs; researchers noted that it is difficult to determine if language deficits are related to epilepsy or AEDs(28)Assess speech and articulation; document presence of reduced speech intelligibility as a result of apraxia (motor planning impairment) or dysarthria (muscle weakness/reduced coordination of oral motor movements) -For detailed information on symptoms, assessment, and treatment of apraxia, please see Clinical Review…Apraxia ofT708586 and Clinical Review…Speech Sound DisordersT708888 -For detailed information on symptoms, assessment, and treatment of dysarthria, please see the series of Clinical Reviews on dysarthriaStandardized tests of language used in research with patients with epilepsy include(5) standardized test of expressive and receptive language skills as well as visual-spatial  and quantitative skills; for use with adults (age 18 and older)(5,22,23) standardized test of confrontation-naming  ability; for use with adults (norms provided for persons aged 18 to 89)(18) standardized test of children’s spoken and written language; subtests measure oral language, reading, writing, and spelling; normed for children 5 years 0 months through 12 years 11 monthsnormed for persons aged 2 years 6 months to 90 years; standardized test for receptive vocabulary(18)(5) standardized test that assesses expressive and receptive language skillsAssess vocal quality and other appropriate voice parameters (e.g., intensity, pitch, range); neurological impairment can affect vocal quality. Refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full evaluation -For detailed information on voice disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicRule out or identify atypical speech disfluencies (stuttering) -For detailed information on disorders of fluency, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicWhen age appropriate, assess reading and writing skills as part of a complete evaluation of communication; portions of standardized tests for aphasia provide standardized tests of both reading and writing -For detailed information on acquired reading disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on acquired dyslexiaSpeech Therapy ; CINAHLT708854Assess swallowing function with a bedside swallowing examination (BSE) if there are concerns about swallowing and aspiration risk –It might be necessary to perform an instrumental evaluation of swallowing (such as a videofluoroscopic swallow study [VFSS] or fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing [FEES]) to rule out aspiration –For detailed information on evaluations of swallowing disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on in-depth BSEs and instrumental evaluations of swallowing (e.g., VFSS, FEES)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with epilepsy might experience a period of confusion during and after a seizure.(2,7) Cognitive deficits sometimes persist beyond the time period immediately surrounding a seizure –The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) and the Neurobehavioral Cognitive Status Examination (NCSE) are evidence-based  screening tools for cognitive functioning(20,21)assesses overall cognitive impairment; sections include Orientation to Time, Orientation to Place, Registration, Attention and Calculation, Recall, Naming, Repetition, Comprehension, Reading, Writing, and Drawing(20)assesses orientation, attention, auditory and visual memory, spatial perceptual skills, calculations, and reasoning; skills are scored separately so that specific deficits can be identified(21)An oral mechanism examination should be completed in all patients withIs the face symmetrical at rest? Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? Are there any abnormal movements (twitching, spasms, grimacing)? Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?Are the lips symmetrical at rest? Are the lips symmetrical during movements? Is the range of motion normal? Is the strength normal? Is the lip tissue healthy? Is there any scarring or cleft? -Authors of a study conducted in Australia with 11 individuals (10 of whom had epilepsy) with speech impairment associated with dysfunction of the GRIN2A  gene reported reduced lingual range of motion and poor lingual coordination among several of the study subjects(36)Is the tongue normal in appearance? Any atrophy? Any discolorations? Any bleeding? Is the range of motion normal? Is the strength normal? Are abnormal or involuntary movements of the tongue present? -Authors of a study conducted in Australia with 11 individuals (10 of whom had epilepsy) with speech impairment associated with dysfunction of the GRIN2A  gene reported the presence of abnormal lingual movements and posturing present during oral motor assessment(36)Is the hard palate intact? Any signs of fistulas, fissures, scarring? Are the height and width normal? Any prostheses present? Is the coloration normal? –Soft palate -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; fogging or clouding might indicate nasal emission, which would indicate the need for a referral to the otolaryngologistAre there any missing teeth? Are the teeth in good repair? Does the patient wear braces or retainers? Is there a significant overbite or underbite?
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve; for detailed information on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve ; CINAHL Topic IDT708919

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the  potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with epilepsy most likely present with some type of speech, language, and/or cognitive deficits. Goals of speech therapy will be determined following a thorough evaluation by the SLP
assessment plan of care.rule out: Epilepsy syndrome is characterized by persistent, unprovoked seizure activity. The patient’s medical team will rule out seizures of known causes, such as febrile seizures and seizures associated with acute systemic illness, intoxication, substance abuse or withdrawal, or acute neurological insult (such as head injury or stroke).(1) The medical team will also rule out other conditions such as: Hypoglycemia(14) Migraines(14) Panic attacks(14) Paroxysmal movement disorders(14)condition most often misdiagnosed as epilepsy; conversion disorder resulting in pseudoseizures(14) Sleep disorders(14) Transient global amnesia(14) Transient ischemic attack (TIA)(14)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The following referrals might be appropriate for patients who present with epilepsy Referral to psychotherapy in the case of suspected PNEAs(14) Referral to an endocrinologist might be appropriate for all patients with epilepsy due to the possibility of AEDs affecting thyroid function as well as comorbidities related to hormones(10) Refer to ophthalmologist if vision problems are noted or reported by the patient during examination Refer to audiologist and/or otolaryngologist if patient fails hearing screening and/or appears to have difficulty hearing during the evaluation Refer to learning disabilities specialist if parents or teachers of a child with epilepsy report difficulty in school subjects
other considerations: Patients with epilepsy who are at a higher risk for SUDEP are those with generalized tonic-clonic  seizures, an early age of epilepsy onset, symptomatic epilepsy, comorbid intellectual disability, who have experienced an unusually stressful life event, are on multiple AEDs, and/or are young and male(10)
treatment summary: Authors of a case study conducted in the United States with a 61-year-old  male patient with temporal lobe epilepsy (acquired at the age of 50) reported a treatment protocol to address proper-name retrieval deficits. The patient experienced ongoing seizure activity throughout the intervention period. Initial language evaluation revealed that the patient had average to high-average  performance on verbal and visual memory tests, mild word-finding  deficits for common nouns, and moderate difficulty with proper-name  retrieval (70% accuracy). The patient also reported problems recalling names in social situations. For treatment stimuli, researchers selected 20 items (famous persons or places) that were familiar to the patient, but not named correctly at baseline; 10 of these items were trained and 10 were used as controls. Treatment  protocol involved 2 hours of training per day for 5 days; all of the stimuli were delivered on a computer screen. For each training picture, the patient was asked to name the item only if he felt confident in his answer. Regardless of whether the patient correctly named the person/place, the therapist then provided verbally semantic features (e.g., “He is an American actor”), showed two additional picture exemplars of the person/place, provided the patient with the number of target syllables and initial/total sounds in the name, and finally showed the picture along with the written name. The patient was then asked to write and say the name 3 times each. Immediately following the training protocol, the patient was 90–100% accurate naming trained items in probe sessions as well as in the sessions 3 months later. There was no change in accuracy of naming untrained items (accuracy was 50% or less in each assessment)(32) ›The following are suggestions from the literature as well as references to Clinical Reviews that address various deficits . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Aphasia Improve receptive and/ or expressive language skillsFunctional training _ Patient and/or family/ caregiver is trained to use strategies or techniques appropriate for the patient’s specific language deficits _ _ (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of aphasia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic)Progression will vary according to specific goals of the patientHome program will vary with respect to the goals of the patient Anomia Improve word-finding abilitiesFunctional training _ _ Examples include:
Train patient to utilize word-finding strategies

Improve word-finding abilities through tasks specifically targeting word-finding _ _ (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of anomia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic)Patient will improve in naming tasks beginning at the word level and progressing to conversational speech requiring fewer cues from the SLP and eventually becoming independent in the use of strategiesHome program will vary with respect to the goals of the patient  Dysarthria/oral-motor deficitsImprove speech intelligibilitySpeech intelligibility strategies _ Examples include:
Use of exaggerated articulation to produce intelligible speech; SLP will educate the patient on how to make appropriately exaggerated articulatory movements

Train patient and caregivers to improve communication efficacy: make eye contact, ensure adequate lighting, use nonverbal enhancements such as writing or communication boards _ _ (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see series of Clinical Reviews on this topic)The patient practices speech intelligibility strategies in syllables, with word lists, sentences, and eventually conversational speechHome program will vary with respect to the goals of the patient Acquired apraxia of speechImprove fluency of speech; to improve speech outputFunctional training _ Train patient to utilize pacing strategies to improve fluency of speech _ _ (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of acquired apraxia of speech, seeClinical Review… Apraxia of Speech (Acquired) , referenced above)The patient practices pacing strategies in syllables, with word lists, sentences, and eventually conversational speechHome program will vary with respect to the goals of the patient .

maintenance or prevention: By identifying seizure triggers, patients and caregivers might be able to prevent some seizures(2)
The Epilepsy Foundation provides a “self-evaluation  tool” online to assess how well an individual patient’s epilepsy is being controlled(2)

Maintenance of speech/language skills will depend on continued use of strategies and techniques acquired in therapy Patients with poorly controlled epilepsy/frequent seizures might have more difficulty maintaining skills acquired in speech therapy
Speech, language, or cognitive deficits that result as side effects of medications might be prevented by working with a patient’s physician to determine the best possible drug treatment regimen
patient education: The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) is an association of physicians and other health professionals whose vision is to create “a world in which no person’s life is limited by epilepsy.” National chapters of this organization may be found in over 100 different countries; view its website at https://www.ilae.org/
The Epilepsy Foundation is a nonprofit organization dedicated to epilepsy education and providing resources to patients with epilepsy; view its website at https://www.epilepsy.com/ Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on November 4, 2016  Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
